"http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4778068/index.html", "body": "Neymar was denied the chance to make his debut in Saturday's win over Amiens\n\nIt's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league.\n\nNeymar's world record \u00a3198million transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar is facing an anxious wait to see whether he can play against Guingamp on Sunday\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos player was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league wrote in an email Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe French league added that it 'does not understand' why its Spanish counterpart 'refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.'\n\nNeymar talks to compatriots Dani Alves (left) and Lucas Moura during a PSG training session\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of their its players out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further. The club did not immediately answer a message from The Associated Press seeking comments.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure 'Spain did everything' to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG without delay.\n\nFrench football federation president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the current turmoil within the Spanish federation.\n\nNeymar watched on from the Parc des Princes stands as PSG beat Amiens on Saturday\n\nAngel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n'I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,' Le Graet told L'Equipe. 'The transfer is complete, so this should not last.'\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.", "time": "11:04:00"}

"1292416"}], "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/soccer/neymars-debut-in-french-league-could-be-delayed-again/article35934443/", "body": "It's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league.\n\nNeymar's world-record 222 million euros ($262 million) transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos forward was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league said in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe French league added that it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the 222 million euros available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further. The club did not immediately answer a message from The Associated Press seeking comments.\n\nFIFA told the AP that it \"has not been contacted by the FFF (French football federation) in connection with the player Neymar and the ITC procedure.\"\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG without delay.\n\nFFF president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the current turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.", "time": "15:11:00"}

when they travel to Guingamp in their second game of the Ligue 1 season.\n\nHowever, the French league are still waiting on a transfer certificate from the Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) before the Brazilian can finally play.\n\nThe certificate has to arrive before Sunday if Neymar is to take to the pitch at the Stade du Roudourou this weekend, with it possible that FIFA may have to intervene if the RFEF do not send the document by Friday.\n\nNeymar pledges glory for PSG after setting new transfer record\n\nBut the French Football Federation (FFF) appear confident that the saga surrounding Neymar, who cost PSG a staggering world record of \u20ac222m, is near its end.\n\n\"The transfer is complete, so this should not last,\" FFF president Noel Le Graet told sports daily L'Equipe. \"The federation is in contact with our Spanish counterparts. There is no reason for this hold-up to continue. These are complicated deals, but there is no missing document today. I do not need to tell you that there are a few problems within the Spanish federation. I do not doubt that this will be quickly solved. Wolves do not eat each other, you know.\"\n\nNeymar deal makes financial sense, says PSG chief\n\nNeymar watched from the Parc des Princes stands as PSG cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener last time out, and coach Unai Emery will want the forward available sooner rather than later.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" he said. \"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better. The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"", "time": "15:03:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stade_du_Roudourou", "label": {"eng": "Stade du Roudourou"}, "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "id": "1239923"}], "url": "http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/514863/Sports/Neymar", "body": "PARIS -- It's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league. Neymar's world-record 222 million euros ($262 million) transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time. Neymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos forward was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league said in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe league however said Neymar could still be qualified for Sunday's game if PSG and the French federation decide against referring the issue to FIFA after the deadline expires.\n\n\"If the French federation does not start proceedings with FIFA, we could still receive the ICT up until Saturday night,\" the league said.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further. The club did not immediately answer a message from The Associated Press seeking comments.\n\nFIFA told the AP that it \"has not been contacted by the FFF (French football federation) in connection with the player Neymar and the ITC procedure.\"\n\nThe French league added that it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the 222 million euros available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG without delay.\n\nFFF president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the current turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates. -- AP", "time": "03:37:00"}

"http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/soccer/2017/08/neymars_debut_in_french_league_could_be_delayed_again?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%253A%2Bbostonherald%252Fsports%252Fsoccer%2B%2528Revolution%2B%2526%2BSoccer%2B-%2BBostonHerald.com%2529&utm_content=FeedBurner", "body": "PARIS -- It's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league.\n\nNeymar's world-record 222 million euros ($262 million) transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos forward was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league said in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe league however said Neymar could still be qualified for Sunday's game if PSG and the French federation decide against referring the issue to FIFA after the deadline expires.\n\n\"If the French federation does not start proceedings with FIFA, we could still receive the ICT up until Saturday night,\" the league said.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further. The club did not immediately answer a message from The Associated Press seeking comments.\n\nFIFA told the AP that it \"has not been contacted by the FFF (French football federation) in connection with the player Neymar and the ITC procedure.\"\n\nThe French league added that it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the 222 million euros available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG without delay.\n\nFFF president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the current turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.\n\n___\n\nJoe Wilson, in Barcelona, Spain, and AP Sports Writer Rob Harris in London contributed to this report.", "time": "21:26:00"}

"http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/neymar-psg-presentation-french-league-1.4242854", "body": "Justin Bieber plays soccer with Neymar at Barcelona's training camp\n\nIt's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league.\n\nNeymar's world-record $262 million US transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season last week at the Parc des Princes against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but was allowed only to watch from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nHe was then expected to play this Sunday at Guingamp.\n\nBut the French league said in a message to The Associated Press that it had not received the ITC from the Spanish federation by the midnight local time deadline on Thursday.\n\nThe French league sent an application for the document last Thursday, following the payment of the player's release clause to Barcelona.\n\nThe league, however, said Neymar could still be qualified for Sunday's game if PSG and the French federation decide against referring the issue to FIFA.\n\n\"If the French federation does not start proceedings with FIFA, we could still receive the ITC up until Saturday night,\" the league said.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further.\n\nFIFA told the AP it \"has not been contacted by the FFF [French Football Federation] in connection with the player Neymar and the ITC procedure.\"\n\nThe French league added it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the funds available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG in time.\n\nFFF president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran Spanish soccer since 1988, was suspended last month from the presidency for one year by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in corruption.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has been making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.", "time": "23:31:00"}

delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos player was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might Angel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. "1292416"}], "url": "http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/neymar-s-debut-in-french-league-could-be-delayed-again-081017-2", "body": "PARIS (AP) It's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league.\n\nNeymar's world-record 222 million euros ($262 million) transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos forward was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league said in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe French league added that it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the 222 million euros available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further. The club did not immediately answer a message from The Associated Press seeking comments.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG without delay.\n\nFrench football federation president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the current turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.\n\n--\n\nJoe Wilson in Barcelona, Spain, contributed.", "time": "11:38:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_association_football_transfers", "label": {"eng": "List of most expensive association football transfers"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "1292416"}], "url": "http://www.eagletribune.com/region/neymar-s-debut-in-french-league-delayed-again/article_b8461a0c-fd34-5d2e-ac2b-7a540f2df313.html", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- It's been nearly a week since Neymar landed in Paris, and the world's most expensive player still can't play for his new club in the French league.\n\nNeymar's world-record 222 million euros ($262 million) transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season last week at the Parc des Princes against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but was allowed only to watch from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nHe was then expected to play this Sunday at Guingamp.\n\nBut the French league said in a message to The Associated Press that it had not received the ITC from the Spanish federation by the midnight local time deadline on Thursday.\n\nThe French league sent an application for the document last Thursday, following the payment of the player's release clause to Barcelona.\n\nThe league, however, said Neymar could still be qualified for Sunday's game if PSG and the French federation decide against referring the issue to FIFA.\n\n\"If the French federation does not start proceedings with FIFA, we could still receive the ITC up until Saturday night,\" the league said.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further.\n\nFIFA told the AP it \"has not been contacted by the FFF (French Football Federation) in connection with the player Neymar and the ITC procedure.\"\n\nThe French league added it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the 222 million euros available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG in time.\n\nFFF president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran Spanish soccer since 1988, was suspended last month from the presidency for one year by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in corruption.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.\n\n-- -- --\n\nJoe Wilson, in Barcelona, Spain, and AP Global Soccer Writer Rob Harris in London contributed.", "time": "23:08:00"}

"type": "wiki", "id": "479861"}], "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/football/neymars-transfer-certificate-received-by-french-federation-4792418/", "body": "By: AP | Paris | Published:August 11, 2017 5:57 pm PSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes but his debut was delayed because of the paperwork issues. (Source: Reuters) Neymar might have to wait longer for PSG debutFans chant 'Neymar die' as Barcelona host Chapecoense, watch videoPSG recover 1 million euros even before Neymar kicks ball\n\nNeymar is expected to make his long-awaited debut with Paris Saint-Germain on Sunday in the small Britany town of Guingamp after French football authorities finally received the Brazil star's international transfer certificate (ITC).\n\nThe French football federation said on Friday it had received the document from its Spanish counterpart, more than a week after PSG signed the Brazilian from Barcelona.\n\nThe French football league then told The Associated Press that the ITC had been submitted by the federation and that Neymar's transfer would be ratified later Friday, clearing the way for him to play at Guingamp on Sunday night.\n\nThe hold-up prevented Neymar from making his PSG debut last Saturday against Amiens after completing his world-record 222 million euro ($262 million) transfer.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes but his debut was delayed because of the paperwork issues. Neymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday but could only watch from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nBarcelona said there was nothing strange about the situation and that the wait was due to the banks. A few hours before the French federation confirmed it had received the ITC, several Spanish media reported on Friday that the 222 million euros had finally been made available in the club's accounts.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG in time.\n\nEmery has yet to announce his squad for the trip to Guingamp but it is very unlikely Neymar will not be included. PSG made clear he would have played against Amiens if not for the paperwork issues. After partying with friends in southern France, Neymar has returned to training with his teammates this week.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Neymar", "time": "12:44:00"}

($262 million) transfer from Barcelona to Paris Saint-Germain was completed last week, but the Brazil international has yet to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos player was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league said in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe French league added that it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of their its players out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further. The club did not immediately answer a message from The Associated Press seeking comments.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG without delay.\n\nFrench football federation president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the current turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran the Spanish soccer federation since 1988, was suspended from the presidency for one year in July by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in a case of misappropriation of private and public funds received by the federation since 2009.\n\n\"I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,\" Le Graet told L'Equipe. \"The transfer is complete, so this should not last.\"\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends. Neymar has since returned to training with his teammates.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "time": "10:15:00"}

"http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/football/neymar-braced-for-french-culture-shock-in-psg-debut-4795364/", "body": "By: PTI | Published:August 13, 2017 10:40 pm Neymar has hinted that his father was against the PSG move. (Source: Reuters) Neymar PSG debut lifts France to fever pitchHard cash, soft power: Neymar's price a small one for Qatar royal familyNeymar's transfer certificate received by French federation\n\nAfter dazzling Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, the world's most expensive footballer Neymar will be welcomed to French football today at Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou in sleepy Brittany.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting 11, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential havoc he could wreak on the home defence.\n\n\"I want the fans to come on Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it,\" he said.\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree -- former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014, and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat, whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -30 more than usual.\n\nNeymar will simply be glad to put his tax troubles behind him and get back to doing what he does best after his lawyer revealed on Saturday that the Brazilian superstar has agreed to pay a $2.5 million fine for tax evasion in his homeland.\n\nHis 2013 transfer to Barca from Sau Paulo's Santos is also the subject of a Spanish tax fraud investigation.\n\n- 1,200km away, Barca start new era -\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the expense of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd while he's not a like-for-like replacement, Spanish press claim former Tottenham Hotspur midfielder Paulinho, a Brazil international, is on the verge of a 40-million-euro move to Barca from China's Guangzhou Evergrande.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Neymar", "time": "17:39:00"}

"type": "wiki", "id": "479861"}], "url": "http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/soccer/2017/08/neymars_transfer_certificate_received_by_french_federation", "body": "PARIS -- Neymar is expected to make his long-awaited debut with Paris Saint-Germain on Sunday in the small Brittany town of Guingamp after French football authorities finally received the Brazil star's international transfer certificate (ITC).\n\nThe French football federation said on Friday it had received the document from its Spanish counterpart, more than a week after PSG signed the Brazilian from Barcelona.\n\nThe French football league then told The Associated Press that the ITC had been submitted by the federation and that Neymar's transfer would be ratified later Friday, clearing the way for him to play at Guingamp on Sunday night.\n\nThe hold-up prevented Neymar from making his PSG debut last Saturday against Amiens after completing his world-record 222 million euro ($262 million) transfer.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes but his debut was delayed because of the paperwork issues. Neymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday but could only watch from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nBarcelona said there was nothing strange about the situation and that the wait was due to the banks. A few hours before the French federation confirmed it had received the ITC, several Spanish media reported on Friday that the 222 million euros had finally been made available in the club's accounts.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said he was not sure \"Spain did everything\" to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG in time.\n\nEmery has yet to announce his squad for the trip to Guingamp but it is very unlikely Neymar will not be included. After partying with friends in southern France, Neymar has returned to training with his teammates this week and Emery said he wants him to start on Sunday.\n\n\"We all want him to start playing,\" Emery told a press conference on Friday. \"We want him in the squad, and in the starting XI. He has trained well, and we have also worked on tactical aspects and set pieces. He is ready.\"", "time": "22:54:00"}

"https://www.iol.co.za/sport/soccer/world-leagues/neymar-braced-for-psg-debut-and-french-culture-shock-10770033", "body": "PARIS - He has dazzled Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, but it's Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou, tucked away in sleepy Brittany, which on Sunday greets Neymar, the world's most expensive footballer.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouar\u00e9, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential for destruction at the feet of the Brazilian superstar.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar. The people here support their team.\"\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival which draws visitors from around the world.\n\nFrom Paris \u1f6eb to Guingamp \u1f6ec !\n\n\u1f534\u1f535 #AllezParis pic.twitter.com/onoHa2jPL5\n\n-- PSG English (@PSG_English) August 12, 2017\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014 and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture, the capital city club's second defeat in four visits to Guingamp since their hosts were promoted in 2013.\n\nFurthermore, former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible.\"\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\n- 1,200km away, Barca start new era -\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline on Saturday in a light-hearted reference to how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news despite Neymar not yet having kicked a ball in anger.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd the Spanish international took his chance with a goal and two assists in just 45 minutes on the field.\n\nAFP\n\nLike us on Facebook\n\nFollow us on Twitter", "time": "13:48:00"}

"http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/13/364724/neymar-braced-for-psg-debut-and-french-culture-shock/", "body": "PARIS: He has dazzled Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, but it's Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou, tucked away in sleepy Brittany, which on Sunday greets Neymar, the world's most expensive footballer.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouar\u00e9, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential for destruction at the feet of the Brazilian superstar.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar. The people here support their team.\"\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival which draws visitors from around the world.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014 and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture, the capital city club's second defeat in four visits to Guingamp since their hosts were promoted in 2013.\n\nFurthermore, former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible.\"\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\n- 1,200km away, Barca start new era -\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline on Saturday in a light-hearted reference to how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news despite Neymar not yet having kicked a ball in anger.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd the Spanish international took his chance with a goal and two assists in just 45 minutes on the field.", "479861"}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4780264/index.html", "body": "The issue could now be referred to FIFA but Neymar would appear unfazed\n\nNeymar's eagerly anticipated debut for Paris Saint-Germain must wait for another week after the Brazilian was denied permission to play in Ligue 1 due to a delay over his paperwork.\n\nThe French authorities have still not received clearance following his world record \u20ac222m (\u00a3200m) move from Barcelona, with the Spanish federation still holding his international transfer certificate.\n\nLigue 1 clubs had until midnight French time on Thursday to register players for the forthcoming game week, meaning Neymar may have to wait a little longer before making his debut.\n\nParis Saint-Germain star Neymar appeared downbeat having lost a game of cards with friends\n\nThe 25-year-old attacker swapped Barcelona for PSG in a world record move this summer\n\nThe league, however, said Neymar could still be qualified for Sunday's game if PSG and the French federation decide against referring the issue to FIFA.\n\n'If the French federation does not start proceedings with FIFA, we could still receive the ITC up until Saturday night,' the league said.\n\nAccording to French newspaper L'Equipe, PSG is unlikely to ask FIFA to rule on the issue because it could slow down proceedings further.\n\nFIFA said it 'has not been contacted by the FFF (French Football Federation) in connection with the player Neymar and the ITC procedure.'\n\nNeymar trains with his new Paris Saint-Germain team-mates but he must wait for his debut\n\nThe French league added it 'does not understand' why its Spanish counterpart 'refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.'\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the \u20ac222m available in the club's account before the transfer is authorised.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.\n\nAsked about his views on the issue after the Amiens game, PSG coach Unai Emery said last week he was not sure 'Spain did everything' to ensure Neymar would be cleared to play for PSG in time.\n\nFFF president Noel Le Graet said another reason for the delay could be the turmoil within the Spanish federation. Angel Maria Villar, who ran Spanish soccer since 1988, was suspended last month from the presidency for one year by Spain's top sports authority for his suspected involvement in corruption.\n\nThe Brazilian is facing an anxious wait before he can make his debut for his new side\n\nNeymar was named in Brazil's squad for the forthcoming World Cup qualifiers in September\n\n'I don't need to tell you that the Spanish federation is having some problems at the moment,' Le Graet told L'Equipe. 'The transfer is complete, so this should not last.'\n\nIn any case, the paperwork issues have left Neymar unfazed. He has making the most of his time off to head to Saint-Tropez, where he has been photographed partying with friends.\n\nDespite the frustration, Neymar has shown he hasn't lost any of his competitive streak during a card game with team-mate Lucas Moura and friends.\n\nWearing a black hoodie and baseball cap, the 25-year-old shrugged his shoulders for the photo posted on his Instagram account.\n\nLucas flaunts his deck, seemingly happy with his performance, with Neymar posting in Portuguese: 'The girls wanted to win and we let them, but Lucas was on their side!'", "time": "23:17:00"}

"type": "wiki", "id": "479861"}], "url": "http://sports.abs-cbn.com/football/news/2017/08/12/neymar-finally-make-psg-debut-sunday-29633", "body": "Brazilian soccer star Neymar waves to fans as he The Brazil star became the most expensive player in soccer history after completing his blockbuster transfer from Barcelona for 222 million euros ($262 million) on Thursday. (AP Photo/Francois Mori)\n\nBy Samuel Petrequin, Associated Press\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Neymar is expected to make his much-awaited debut for Paris Saint-Germain on Sunday in the small Brittany town of Guingamp after French football authorities finally received his international transfer certificate.\n\nThe French Football Federation received the document from its Spanish counterpart on Friday, more than a week after PSG signed the Brazilian from Barcelona.\n\nThe French football league then told The Associated Press the ITC was submitted by the federation, and Neymar's transfer would be ratified later Friday, clearing the way for him to play at Guingamp on Sunday.\n\nThe hold-up prevented Neymar from making his PSG debut last Saturday against Amiens after completing his world-record 222 million euros ($262 million) transfer.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at its Parc des Princes home but his debut was delayed because of the paperwork issues. Neymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday but could only watch from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nBarcelona said there was nothing strange about the situation and the wait was due to the banks. Just a few hours before the French federation said it had received the ITC, the 222 million euros was made available in Barcelona's accounts.\n\nBarcelona denied speculation that slowed down the process in retaliation for PSG luring one of its biggest stars out of the Camp Nou. Barcelona said it had been waiting on the banks to complete the transaction for the massive amount of money.\n\nPSG coach Unai Emery has yet to announce his squad for the trip to Guingamp, but wants Neymar to be playing.\n\n\"We all want him to start playing,\" Emery told a news conference on Friday. \"We want him in the squad, and in the starting 11. He has trained well, and we have also worked on tactical aspects and set-pieces. He is ready.\"\n\n___", "time": "23:37:00"}

"http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/6/55/275258/Sports/World/Neymar-braced-for-PSG-debut-and-French-culture-sho.aspx", "body": "Paris Saint-Germain's Brazilian forward Neymar attends a training session at the Camp des Loges in Saint-Germain-en-Laye, near Paris, on August 11, 2017 AFP\n\nHe has dazzled Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, but it's Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou, tucked away in sleepy Brittany, which on Sunday greets Neymar, the world's most expensive footballer.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouar\u00e9, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential for destruction at the feet of the Brazilian superstar.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar. The people here support their team.\"\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival which draws visitors from around the world.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014 and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture, the capital city club's second defeat in four visits to Guingamp since their hosts were promoted in 2013.\n\nFurthermore, former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible.\"\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\n- 1,200km away, Barca start new era -\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline on Saturday in a light-hearted reference to how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news despite Neymar not yet having kicked a ball in anger.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd the Spanish international took his chance with a goal and two assists in just 45 minutes on the field.", "time": "11:40:00"}

to be granted permission to play.\n\nPSG wanted Neymar to start the season at the Parc des Princes last week against Amiens but his debut was delayed because his international transfer certificate (ITC) had not been received by the French league on time.\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans on Saturday, but watched from the stands as his new team started its league campaign with a 2-0 win.\n\nThe former Santos forward was then expected to play on Sunday night at Guingamp at the 18,000-capacity Stade du Roudourou, but PSG fans might have to wait a bit longer to see the star in action.\n\nThe French league said in an email to The Associated Press on Thursday that it had not received the document needed from the Spanish federation. It added the deadline for receiving the document was midnight local time.\n\nThe French league added that it \"does not understand\" why its Spanish counterpart \"refuses to accept the payment for the buyout clause for Neymar.\"\n\nBarcelona said there is nothing strange about the situation and that the wait is due to the banks, which have to make the 222 million euros available in the club's account before the transfer is authorized.\n\nThere has been speculation in France that Barcelona slowed down the whole process as a retaliation measure against PSG after the French league club lured one of its three biggest stars out of the Camp Nou.", "time": "23:22:00"}

There is no reason for this hold-up to continue. These are complicated deals, but there is no missing document today. I do not need to tell you that there are a few problems within the Spanish federation. I do not doubt that this will be quickly solved. Wolves do not eat each other, you know.\"\n\nNeymar watched from the Parc des Princes stands as PSG cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener last time out, and coach Unai Emery will want the forward available sooner rather than later.\n\nThe 25-year-old scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\nSpaniard Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals, whether he makes his debut on Sunday or the following week against Toulouse.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" he said.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, who are desperately trying to hang on to rising star Kylian Mbappe in the face of serious interest from Real Madrid.\n\nThe 18-year-old started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.", "time": "12:26:00"}

Neymar is poised to make his much-anticipated debut for Paris Saint-Germain on Sunday when they travel to Guingamp in their second game of the Ligue 1 season.\n\nHowever, the French league are still waiting on a transfer certificate from the Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) before the Brazilian can finally play.\n\nThe certificate has to arrive before Sunday if Neymar is to take to the pitch at the Stade du Roudourou this weekend, with it possible that FIFA may have to intervene if the RFEF do not send the document by Friday.\n\nBut the French Football Federation (FFF) appear confident that the saga surrounding Neymar, who cost PSG a staggering world record of 222 million euros ($264m), is near its end.\n\n\"The transfer is complete, so this should not last,\" FFF president Noel Le Graet told sports daily L'Equipe.\n\n\"The federation is in contact with our Spanish counterparts. There is no reason for this hold-up to continue.\n\nNeymar left Barcelona for Paris Saint-Germain in a world record transfer \u00a9 AFP/File / LLUIS GENE\n\n\"These are complicated deals, but there is no missing document today.\n\n\"I do not need to tell you that there are a few problems within the Spanish federation. I do not doubt that this will be quickly solved. Wolves do not eat each other, you know.\"\n\nNeymar watched from the Parc des Princes stands as PSG cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener last time out, and coach Unai Emery will want the forward available sooner rather than later.\n\nThe 25-year-old scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\nSpaniard Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals, whether he makes his debut on Sunday or the following week against Toulouse.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" he said.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, who are desperately trying to hang on to rising star Kylian Mbappe in the face of serious interest from Real Madrid.\n\nThe 18-year-old started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nLigue 1 fixtures (all times GMT)\n\nFriday\n\nNice v Troyes (1700), Rennes v Lyon (1845)\n\nSaturday\n\nNantes v Marseille (1500), Amiens v Angers (1800), Bordeaux v Metz (1800), Caen v Saint-Etienne (1800), Toulouse v Montpellier (1800)\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille (1300), Dijon v Monaco (1500), Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain (1900)\n\nShares", "time": "14:13:00"}

Barcelona.\n\nThe French giants paid \u00a3198million for the Brazilian attacker and is prepared to fork out another huge figure on Mbappe.\n\nMonaco do not want to sell Mbappe after losing several of their best players to other clubs this summer.\n\nMidfielder Tiemoue Bakayoko left for Chelsea, while Bernardo Silva and Benjamin Mendy are both now City players.\n\nMonaco are refusing to entertain Mbappe's exit, but there is hope from the player he will be allowed leave in the coming weeks.\n\nA bid from PSG could be submitted in the coming week with the Parisians considering an opening offer expensive footballer Neymar will be welcomed to French football today at Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou in sleepy Brittany.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting 11, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential havoc he could wreak on the home defence.\n\n\"I want the fans to come on Sunday to see Guingamp win...\n\npreferably against a side with Neymar in it,\" he said.\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree -- former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014, and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat, whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\nNeymar will simply be glad to put his tax troubles behind him and get back to doing what he does best after his lawyer revealed on Saturday that the Brazilian superstar has agreed to pay a $2.5 million fine for tax evasion in his homeland.\n\nHis 2013 transfer to Barca from Sau Paulo's Santos is also the subject of a Spanish tax fraud investigation.\n\n- 1,200km away, Barca start new era - ===================================== Meanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the expense of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd while he's not a like-for-like replacement, Spanish press claim former Tottenham Hotspur midfielder Paulinho, a Brazil international, is on the verge of a 40-million-euro move to Barca from China's Guangzhou Evergrande.\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "time": "15:55:00"}

"http://www.firstpost.com/sports/ligue-1-neymar-set-for-highly-anticipated-debut-as-paris-saint-germain-face-guingamp-3926379.html", "body": "Paris: After dazzling Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, the world's most expensive footballer Neymar will be welcomed to French football on Sunday at Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou in sleepy Brittany.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\nNeymar is set to make his PSG debut against Guingamp on Sunday. AFP\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting 11, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential havoc he could wreak on the home defence.\n\n\"I want the fans to come on Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it,\" he said.\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree -- former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014, and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat, whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\nNeymar will simply be glad to put his tax troubles behind him and get back to doing what he does best after his lawyer revealed on Saturday that the Brazilian superstar has agreed to pay a $2.5 million fine for tax evasion in his homeland.\n\nHis 2013 transfer to Barca from Sau Paulo's Santos is also the subject of a Spanish tax fraud investigation.\n\n1,200km away, Barca start new era\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the expense of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd while he's not a like-for-like replacement, Spanish press claim former Tottenham Hotspur midfielder Paulinho, a Brazil international, is on the verge of a 40-million-euro move to Barca from China's Guangzhou Evergrande.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 13, 2017 05:24 pm | Updated Date: Aug 13, 2017 05:24 pm\n\nTags :#Barcelona#Guingamp#Javier pastore#Kickingaround#Ligue 1#Lionel messi#Luis suarez#Neymar#Paris-saint germain#Psg#Unai emery", "time": "12:23:00"}

There is no reason for this hold-up to continue.\n\n\"These are complicated deals, but there is no missing document today.\n\n\"I do not need to tell you that there are a few problems within the Spanish federation. I do not doubt that this will be quickly solved. Wolves do not eat each other, you know.\"\n\nNeymar watched from the Parc des Princes stands as PSG cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener last time out, and coach Unai Emery will want the forward available sooner rather than later.\n\nThe 25-year-old scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\nSpaniard Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals, whether he makes his debut on Sunday or the following week against Toulouse.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" he said.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, who are desperately trying to hang on to rising star Kylian Mbappe in the face of serious interest from Real Madrid.\n\nThe 18-year-old started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nNantes v Marseille (1500), Amiens v Angers (1800), Bordeaux v Metz (1800), Caen v Saint-Etienne (1800), Toulouse v Montpellier (1800)\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille (1300), Dijon v Monaco (1500), Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain (1900)", "time": "14:28:00"}

There is no reason for this hold-up to continue.\n\n\"These are complicated deals, but there is no missing document today.\n\n\"I do not need to tell you that there are a few problems within the Spanish federation. I do not doubt that this will be quickly solved. Wolves do not eat each other, you know.\"\n\nNeymar watched from the Parc des Princes stands as PSG cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener last time out, and coach Unai Emery will want the forward available sooner rather than later.\n\nThe 25-year-old scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\nSpaniard Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals, whether he makes his debut on Sunday or the following week against Toulouse.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" he said.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, who are desperately trying to hang on to rising star Kylian Mbappe in the face of serious interest from Real Madrid.\n\nThe 18-year-old started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nNantes v Marseille (1500), Amiens v Angers (1800), Bordeaux v Metz (1800), Caen v Saint-Etienne (1800), Toulouse v Montpellier (1800)\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille (1300), Dijon v Monaco (1500), Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain (1900)", "time": "12:32:00"}
