He will be able to play on Sunday,\" said the LFP on Friday.\n\nThe world's most expensive player should therefore run out into the mundane surroundings of the Stade du Roduourou -- capacity just over 15,000 -- in the tiny Brittany town of barely 7,000 people.\n\n\"Quite honestly it's better if he's there, much better,\" said Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, a former PSG player and Paris coach from 2009 to 2011.\n\n\"For us it is an extra source of motivation. We know that by beating PSG with Neymar it would be even more momentous.\n\n\"If Neymar is there it is all the better for the spectacle, for the supporters and for those who want to see him play, but we will be ready with or without him.\"\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans at the Parc des Princes last weekend but was forced to watch from the stands as his new team-mates cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener.\n\nThe 25-year-old Brazilian scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\n- Better with Neymar -\n\nCoach Unai Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\nNeymar left Barcelona for Paris Saint-Germain in a world record transfer \u00a9 AFP/File / LLUIS GENE\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, but they are in serious danger of losing rising star Kylian Mbappe to the capital outfit.\n\nThe 18-year-old, who is also wanted by Real Madrid, started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players, the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nMarseille visit Claudio Ranieri's Nantes on Saturday looking to build on their 3-0 win over Dijon last time out but with captain Dimitri Payet missing due to injury.\n\nLigue 1 fixtures (all times GMT)\n\nFriday\n\nNice v Troyes (1700), Rennes v Lyon (1845)\n\nSaturday\n\nNantes v Marseille (1500), Amiens v Angers (1800), Bordeaux v Metz (1800), Caen v Saint-Etienne (1800), Toulouse v Montpellier (1800)\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille (1300), Dijon v Monaco (1500), Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain (1900)\n\nShares", "time": "13:10:00"}

Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nPARIS: He has dazzled Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, but it's Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou, tucked away in sleepy Brittany, which on Sunday greets Neymar, the world's most expensive footballer.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouar\u00e9, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential for destruction at the feet of the Brazilian superstar.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar. The people here support their team.\"\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival which draws visitors from around the world.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014 and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture, the capital city club's second defeat in four visits to Guingamp since their hosts were promoted in 2013.\n\nFurthermore, former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible.\"\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\n1,200km away, Barca start new era\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline on Saturday in a light-hearted reference to how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news despite Neymar not yet having kicked a ball in anger.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd the Spanish international took his chance with a goal and two assists in just 45 minutes on the field.", "time": "04:30:00"}

He will be able to play on Sunday,\" said the LFP on Friday.\n\nThe world's most expensive player should, therefore, run out into the mundane surroundings of the Stade du Roduourou -- capacity just over 15,000 -- in the tiny Brittany town of barely 7,000 people.\n\n\"Quite honestly it's better if he's there, much better,\" said Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, a former PSG player and Paris coach from 2009 to 2011.\n\n\"For us it is an extra source of motivation. We know that by beating PSG with Neymar it would be even more momentous.\n\n\"If Neymar is there it is all the better for the spectacle, for the supporters and for those who want to see him play, but we will be ready with or without him.\"\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans at the Parc des Princes last weekend but was forced to watch from the stands as his new team-mates cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener.\n\nThe 25-year-old Brazilian scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\n- Better with Neymar -\n\nCoach Unai Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, but they are in serious danger of losing rising star Kylian Mbappe to the capital outfit.\n\nThe 18-year-old, who is also wanted by Real Madrid, started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players, the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nMarseille visit Claudio Ranieri's Nantes on Saturday looking to build on their 3-0 win over Dijon last time out but with captain Dimitri Payet missing due to injury.\n\nNantes v Marseille (1500), Amiens v Angers (1800), Bordeaux v Metz (1800), Caen v Saint-Etienne (1800), Toulouse v Montpellier (1800)\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille (1300), Dijon v Monaco (1500), Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain (1900)", "time": "13:36:00"}

"http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4782138/index.html", "body": "PARIS, Aug 11 (Reuters) - World-record signing Neymar looks set to make his debut for Paris St Germain on Sunday after the French prevented from playing in PSG's first Ligue 1 match of the season against Amiens last week because his registration had gone through too late.\n\nPSG travel to En Avant Guingamp on Sunday.\n\n\"One thing is clear: we want him to make his debut (on Sunday),\" PSG coach Unai Emery told reporters. \"He's been good in training. He is ready. We want him to be in the squad and to start. He's a player we need.\"\n\n\"I think he is ready to start the game.\"\n\nThe French football federation (FFF) confirmed that Neymar was now licensed to play in France.\n\n\"The FFF confirms it has received the transfer certificate of Neymar Jr, sent by the RFEF (Spanish football federation),\" the FFF said on its Twitter feed on Friday.\n\nPSG opened the season by beating Amiens 2-0 at the Parc des Princes last Saturday. They ended last season as runners-up to Monaco after winning four successive Ligue 1 titles. ($1 = 0.8469 euros) (Reporting by Julien Pretot; Editing by Susan Fenton)", "time": "14:00:00"}

"http://sports.inquirer.net/260318/neymar-paris-saint-germain-fbl-fra-ligue1-psg-debut-french-culture-shock", "body": "He has dazzled Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, but it's Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou, tucked away in sleepy Brittany, which on Sunday greets Neymar, the world's most expensive footballer.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouar\u00e9, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential for destruction at the feet of the Brazilian superstar.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar. The people here support their team.\"\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival which draws visitors from around the world.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014 and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture, the capital city club's second defeat in four visits to Guingamp since their hosts were promoted in 2013.\n\nFurthermore, former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible.\"\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\n1,200km away, Barca start new era\n\nMeanwhile, French media speculated over who in the expensively-assembled PSG team will make way for Neymar.\n\nLe Parisien suggested it will be Javier Pastore, the Argentine star who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" Le Parisien asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left for Manchester United last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this summer.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline on Saturday in a light-hearted reference to how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news despite Neymar not yet having kicked a ball in anger.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn hour later, and around 1,200km further south, Barcelona will start their first competitive match without Neymar by facing bitter rivals Real Madrid in the first leg of the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nBarca's scattergun approach to finding a replacement for Neymar has so far been unsuccessful with bids for Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele of Borussia Dortmund rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton and AC Milan.\n\nAnd the Spanish international took his chance with a goal and two assists in just 45 minutes on the field.", "time": "02:38:00"}

"score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "455235"}], "url": "http://deadspin.com/slaving-terrorism-supporting-countrys-wildly-expensive-1797598193", "body": "Qatar is a tiny, obscenely wealthy country/U.S. military base in the Persian Gulf that has, justifiably so, become synonymous of late with dynastic oligarchism, shameless venality, modern-day slavery, and financial support for Islamist terrorism. This, it probably goes without saying, isn't quite the reputation the small number of obscenely rich Qataris who run the country would like their dear nation to have. Thus they've fronted their top public-relations/soft power vessel -- the famed Paris Saint-Germain soccer club -- an ungodly amount of money to get everyone to forget that nasty slavery and terrorism business and associate Qatar with famous and beautiful soccer guys kicking balls into nets and winning trophies. And the record-shattering Neymar transfer was just the start.\n\nAfter spending \u20ac222 million for the right to pry Neymar away from the despairing clutches of Barcelona -- the irony should not be lost here that this is club that broke its high-minded, long time no-shirt-sponsor policy in exchange for Qatar's millions and finally lost their Brazilian jewel the first year in which the team changed sponsors -- and in the process doubling the previous transfer record, PSG are reportedly now preparing to make what would probably wind up the second-highest fee ever. The Parisian club is seriously pushing for the signature of Ligue 1 rivals Monaco's star, Kylian Mbapp\u00e9. If the 25-year-old Neymar is the closest thing the sport has to a \"Next Messi,\" meaning a generational talent the likes of which comprehensively surpasses all others, then the 18-year-old Mbapp\u00e9 is probably the best bet to be the singular star of the generation of players after Neymar's. He is unbelievably good already and had a coming out season so amazing that traditional superclubs like Real Madrid and Barcelona are hot for him. It's only natural that PSG would see this shiny new trinket and go for it.\n\nPSG have, according to reports, been after the French striker all summer. It seemed like the Neymar deal would put them out of the running, seeing as it was already unclear whether the club could even foot that bill without coming under Financial Fair Play punishment, but here we are. Le Parisien reports that PSG believe they can fund both the Neymar deal and the likely \u20ac180 million-plus Mbapp\u00e9 one by selling a few rotation players and renegotiating some sponsorship agreements in light of all their great new fame -- not, of course, that attached to the recent widespread acknowledgement that Qatar funds terrorism (and it will remain forever ironic that saying this clear truth in polite society didn't really become fashionable until shameless terrorism-supporters Saudi Arabia made it A Thing), but instead the fact that Qatar's pet team has the incredibly famous Neymar.\n\nAccording to one report, Mbapp\u00e9 and PSG have actually already agreed to personal terms. The more reputable Le Parisien won't go that far, but they do note both that Mbapp\u00e9 is definitely willing to hear PSG out and that PSG have a pricy backup plan in case Real Madrid or someone else beats them to Mbapp\u00e9. Yes, PSG have apparently listened to their new star's apparent wishes and intend to try for Liverpool's Phillipe Coutinho. It would be the perfect fuck you to Bar\u00e7a if PSG thrice thwarted their Catalan rivals' plans, first by batting away their attempts to sign Marco Verratti, then by snatching away Neymar, and finally by swooping in for Bar\u00e7a's top Neymar-replacement option.\n\nAll this money is almost nauseating to even think about, and that's exactly the point. Qatar, by way of PSG, want you to think of them as an entity so rich and powerful that nothing can prevent them from achieving what they most desire, that even the established powers-that-be must cower before their financial might, and that when their best-laid plans finally, inevitably come to fruition, the result is a product so dazzlingly and stupefyingly great that no one can help but bow down in awe of what they've created. After all, it's a bit harder to remember thousands of faceless poor people dying in deplorable working conditions when the resulting World Cup stadiums are just so damn cool looking, or to think of the thousands of innocent people murdered at the hands of terrorists backed by the Qatari government when the broad smiles and shining faces and stunning highlights of Neymar and Mbapp\u00e9 in their gorgeous PSG shirts are plastered on the TV all the time.", "time": "22:13:00"}

He will be able to play on Sunday,\" said the LFP on Friday.\n\nThe world's most expensive player should therefore run out into the mundane surroundings of the Stade du Roduourou -- capacity just over 15,000 -- in the tiny Brittany town of barely 7,000 people.\n\n\"Quite honestly it's better if he's there, much better,\" said Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, a former PSG player and Paris coach from 2009 to 2011.\n\n\"For us it is an extra source of motivation. We know that by beating PSG with Neymar it would be even more momentous.\n\n\"If Neymar is there it is all the better for the spectacle, for the supporters and for those who want to see him play, but we will be ready with or without him.\"\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans at the Parc des Princes last weekend but was forced to watch from the stands as his new teammates cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener.\n\nThe 25-year-old Brazilian scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\nCoach Unai Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him ... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, but they are in serious danger of losing rising star Kylian Mbappe to the capital outfit.\n\nThe 18-year-old, who is also wanted by Real Madrid, started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players, the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nMarseille visit Claudio Ranieri's Nantes on Saturday looking to build on their 3-0 win over Dijon last time out but with captain Dimitri Payet missing due to injury.\n\nLigue 1 fixtures (kick-offs 10pm UAE time unless stated)\n\nNantes v Marseille (7pm), Amiens v Angers, Bordeaux v Metz, Caen v Saint-Etienne, Toulouse v Montpellier.\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille 5pm, Dijon v Monaco 7pm, Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain 11pm.", "time": "02:43:00"}

"https://www.independent.co.ug/neymar-braced-french-culture-shock-psg-debut/", "body": "Paris, France | AFP | After dazzling Rio's imposing Maracana and Barcelona's storied Camp Nou, the world's most expensive footballer Neymar will be welcomed to French football on Sunday at Guingamp's humble 17,000-capacity Stade du Rouduorou in sleepy Brittany.\n\nWith the mundanity of transfer paperwork finally resolved, the 25-year-old Brazilian magician will line up for Paris Saint-Germain for the first time since his mind-boggling 222 million euro ($261 million) move from Barcelona.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks. We all want him in the starting 11, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nEven Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, himself a former PSG boss, wants Neymar to play despite the potential havoc he could wreak on the home defence.\n\n\"I want the fans to come on Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it,\" he said.\n\nTake one! @NeymarJR named to PSG's roster for tomorrow's match vs. @EAGuingamp ! #NeymarJR10 pic.twitter.com/sd6npiiNld\n\n-- PSG English (@PSG_English) August 12, 2017\n\nIt will be a major culture shock for Neymar in a town which has a population of just 7,000 and is best known for its annual Breton dance showcase, the Saint Loup Festival.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree -- former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014, and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat, whose club budget is an eighth of what PSG paid for Neymar.\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\nNeymar will simply be glad to put his tax troubles behind him and get back to doing what he does best after his lawyer revealed on Saturday that the Brazilian superstar has agreed to pay a $2.5 million fine for tax evasion in his homeland.\n\nHis 2013 transfer to Barca from Sau Paulo's Santos is also the subject of a Spanish tax fraud investigation.", "time": "10:54:00"}

"body": "Kylian Mbappe should turn down a move away from Monaco this summer and stay for one more season, says Eric Abidal.\n\nFrench newspaper L'Equipe is reporting that Paris St-Germain are close to signing striker Mbappe, 18, with a five-year contract already agreed.\n\nAccording to Spanish sports daily Marca, Monaco have accepted PSG's offer of 180 million euros (\u00a3163m).\n\nBut ex-Monaco defender Abidal told BBC World Service Sport's World Football programme: \"It's not the time to move.\"\n\nThe retired former Barcelona player, 37, added: \"It's true that Mbappe has reached a high level really quickly, and he has had an amazing past six months, but now he has to confirm that level.\n\n\"He has to show he can be consistent, perform at a big competition like the World Cup with France, and then make his move.\n\n\"Right now, Monaco is the best club for him. There is not too much pressure. He is a quiet guy, only thinking of work. At a big club, there is pressure every day, and if you don't score, even in one game, it is hard.\"\n\nMbappe, one of the most coveted talents in football, has also been linked with moves to Real Madrid and Manchester City this summer.\n\nIn July, Monaco accused several \"top European clubs\" of making illegal approaches for the teenage forward.\n\nBBC Sport understands City were the only English club accused, although Fifa say they are yet to receive an official complaint.\n\nEarlier in August, PSG completed the \u00a3200m signing of 25-year-old Brazilian forward Neymar from Barcelona.\n\nUnai Emery's side have also brought in 27-year-old Spanish left-back Yuri Berchiche from Real Sociedad and right-back Dani Alves, 34, who joined on a free transfer after leaving Juventus.\n\nThe signing of Mbappe would take their total spend this summer to around \u00a3380m.\n\nPSG is backed by money from Gulf state Qatar and La Liga president Javier Tebas has accused the French club of \"financial doping\".\n\nBefore Neymar's transfer was complete, Barcelona said they would call on Uefa to investigate a possible breach of its Financial Fair Play rules (FFP), which are designed to stop clubs spending more than they earn.\n\nPSG were punished in 2014 for breach of FFP. Their \u00a3167m commercial contract with the Qatar Tourism Authority was deemed to have an unfair value by Uefa's independent investigation panel.\n\nThey were given a \u00a320m fine, their spending was capped to \u00a349m and they competed in the 2014-15 Champions League with just 21 players instead of the usual 25.", "time": "08:15:00"}

destruction at the feet of the Brazilian superstar.\n\nHowever, that's not to say that Guingamp do not have football pedigree.\n\nThey were French Cup winners in 2009 and 2014 and last season beat PSG 2-1 in the corresponding league fixture, the capital city club's second defeat in four visits to Guingamp since their hosts were promoted in 2013.\n\nFurthermore, former Chelsea and Ivory Coast star Didier Drogba spent a season at the club in 2002/2003.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" said Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat whose club budget is an possible.\"\n\nJournalists from far and wide are expected for the game -- the ground's press tribune, built to hold 80 people, has been extended to cater for 350.\n\nA total of 145 stewards will be on duty at the ground -- 30 more than usual.\n\n- 1,200km away, Barca start new era -\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore.\"\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline on Saturday in a light-hearted reference to how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news despite Neymar not yet having kicked a ball in anger.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and Angel di Maria will support (striker) Ederson Cavani,\" predicted L'Equipe.\n\nThe match in Guingamp kicks-off at 1900GMT.\n\nAn rebuffed.\n\nGerard Deulofeu was handed Neymar's role alongside Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez up front in Monday's 5-0 friendly win over Chapecoense on his return to the club after spells at Everton subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nParis Saint-Germain are on the point of adding the \u20ac180million capture of Kylian Mbappe to their unprecedented and controversy-laden \u20ac222m signing of Neymar.\n\nAccording to PSG and Monaco sources, the Qatar-owned club do not intend to stop at creating a forward line of Mbappe, Neymar and Edison Cavani at a combined transfer fee cost of significantly more than \u20ac450m. They also have a deal in place to bring Fabinho from AS Monaco and are attempting to persuade Jan Oblak to join them from Atletico Madrid.\n\nAs The Daily Record reported last month, PSG were one of three clubs to offer Monaco a transfer fee of \u20ac180m for Mbappe, a record sum for a teenager and, following the Ligue 1 side's release-clause recruitment of Neymar, a figure that would be the second highest ever paid for a professional footballer. Real Madrid and Manchester City were also in competition for the striker's signature.\n\nPep Guardiola has led City's efforts to persuade Mbappe to join a club he helped knock out of last season's Champions League, meeting the 18-year-old in person to discuss the proposed move. Madrid's approach has been handicapped by concerns over making space for Mbappe in their Galactico-laden squad, leading the European champions to float a reluctant Gareth Bale on the transfer market.\n\nAll three clubs are willing to meet Mbappe's salary demands, which according to a source familiar with the negotiations, are for a basic salary of between \u20ac7 and \u20ac8m net.\n\nFollowing Madrid's 2-1 UEFA Super Cup victory over Manchester United on Tuesday, Madrid president Florentino Perez told reporters that he did not expect the club to make any acquisitions this month. \"I don't think there will be any more, we already have great players,\" Perez said. \"My and Zidane's idea after winning the Champions League was to do nothing and keep the team as it was.\"\n\nFabinho, who Monaco initially priced at \u20ac45m, was included on the summer recruitment lists of both Guardiola and Jose Mourinho. City were involved in advanced negotiations for a player who can operate both in midfield and as a full back, then stepped away from a deal earlier this summer. United elected to reinforce their midfield with Nemanja Matic from Chelsea, a player with extensive experience of English football and Mourinho's methods.\n\nOblak, 24, is considered one the best goalkeepers in Europe and has been Atletico's No.1 since March 2015. PSG attempted to sign the Slovenia international last summer; his current contract runs until 2021 and includes a \u20ac100m buy-out clause. It is understood the player has reservations about leaving Atletico in the current window as a FIFA transfer ban prevents the club from signing a replacement until January.\n\npoll loading Would PSG boast the world's best attacking line-up? 0+ VOTES SO FAR Yes No Debatable", "time": "16:36:00"}

"http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/football/neymar-psg-debut-lifts-france-to-fever-pitch-4794139/", "body": "Le Parisien daily newspaper suggested it would be Javier Pastore, the silky but fragile Argentine who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners, who splashed out a world record 222 million-euro (USD 261 million) for Neymar. Published:August 12, 2017 10:43 pm Alongside Javier Pastore will be the Brazilian Lucas Moura, who is rumoured to be staying as he has been friends with Neymar since the age of nine. (Source: Reuters) Hard cash, soft power: Neymar's price a small one for Qatar royal familyNeymar's transfer certificate received by French federationNeymar might have to wait longer for PSG debut\n\nAs the hysteria mounts ahead of Neymar's Paris Saint-Germain debut tomorrow focus switched from his record transfer fee to the question of which star would make way for the Brazilian.\n\nLe Parisien daily newspaper suggested it would be Javier Pastore, the silky but fragile Argentine who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners, who splashed out a world record 222 million-euro (USD 261 million) for Neymar.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" one Le Parisien headline asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this season.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore,\" the article claimed. \"So it'll be Neymar, (Edinson) Cavani and without doubt (Angel) di Maria in a three pronged attack,\" said Le Parisien, which then gave a long list of top signings who will be warming the PSG bench.\n\nAlongside Pastore will be the Brazilian Lucas Moura, who is rumoured to be staying as he has been friends with Neymar since the age of nine, and Germany captain at the Confederations Cup Julian Draxler, who arrived just last year in a big money transfer of his own.\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though \"Neymar - the football version,\" ran their headline in the joke about how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news without the 25-year-old forward even kicking a ball yet.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and di Maria will support Cavani,\" they predicted, but were unsure where the extra man would be cut. The only sure thing is that Neymar will start.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP. \"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\" Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouar\u00e9, himself a former PSG\n\nmanager, also wants Neymar to play. \"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win...preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar,\" he claimed. \"The people here support their team.\" In the tiny Brittany town of Guingamp, with a population of around 7,000, tickets for the match have been changing hands for a king's ransom as the Stade du Rouduorou has a capacity of just over 17,000.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat told local newspaper Le Telegramme.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible,\" he said.\n\nJournalists, however, may find themselves a bit squeezed for space as the rustic press tribune allowing for 80 press seats has been extended to a blockbuster 350.\n\nFor all the latest Sports News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: Neymar PSG", "time": "17:19:00"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jocelyn_Gourvennec", "label": {"eng": "Jocelyn Gourvennec"}, "score": 2, "type": "person", "id": "334296"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/En_Avant_de_Guingamp", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camp_des_Loges", "label": {"eng": "Camp des Loges"}, "score": 2, "type": "wiki", "id": "1042164"}], "url": "http://www.espnfc.com/club/paris-saint-germain/160/blog/post/3178365", "body": "GUINGAMP, France -- \"While Neymar is making his debut in front of 18,250 people on Sunday, Barcelona will be playing in front of 99,354 against Real Madrid at Camp Nou.\"\n\n... How many fans would Neymar have played in front of with Barcelona when they are away at Alaves, Eibar, Getafe, Girona & Leganes? https://t.co/DE4fslrpqw - Jonathan Johnson (@Jon_LeGossip)\n\nAugust 11, 2017\n\nThere has been a lot of that this week. Like it means anything.\n\nWhen Barca travel to tiny Eibar's 7,083-capacity Ipurua Municipal Stadium next February, Neymar and his new Paris Saint-Germain side will host recently promoted Strasbourg at Parc des Princes in front of what will probably be close to a 47,929-strong crowd. So?\n\nAlaves, Getafe, Girona and Leganes also play at venues smaller than the Stade de Roudourou -- where Neymar will make his PSG debut on Sunday.\n\nDear @SkyKaveh,\n\n7000 people in the town but better atmosphere than 99000 in Camp Nou. Come @neymarjr !#NeymarAuVillage pic.twitter.com/UuVkopyPW0 - Pierre Henry-Dufeil (@PierreHD)\n\nAugust 7, 2017\n\nLike any major European league, there are big fixtures and smaller ones, and it is simply the luck of the draw when the big teams visit the little ones and vice versa.\n\n\"Ligue 1 is full of farmers.\"\n\nThere have been many of those sorts of comments too since Neymar showed the audacity to leave Barca for PSG in a world-record \u20ac222 million deal.\n\nWrong.\n\nThere are a number of other top sides in Le Championnat, and not just the obvious ones such as Monaco, Nice, Lyon and Marseille.\n\nThe likes of Bordeaux and Saint-Etienne are also capable of competing against the best in France's top flight, so the idea that Neymar has moved to a league completely lacking in quality is a complete non-starter.\n\nIt is ironic, though, that the Brazilian superstar should make his debut this weekend against a team that is reveling in its agricultural image and in many ways fits the lazy, stereotypical image those unfamiliar with Ligue 1 have of the competition.\n\nDespite the fact that they have continually defied the odds to be competing in their fifth consecutive season in Le Championnat, have won the Coupe de France twice -- once while in Ligue 2 -- and represent a commune with a population of just over 7,000, modest En Avant de Guingamp, half-jokingly, actually pride themselves on their image as a farmers club.\n\n#NeymarAuVillage (\"Neymar to the village\") has been trending on Twitter this week ahead of PSG and Neymar's visit to the department of Cotes-d'Armor -- yes, the Internet and Twitter exist in such a sleepy place -- and the club have also been joking about their country bumpkin image, not to mention their love of tractors and menial work.\n\nOn paper, Unai Emery's men should walk all over Antoine Kombouare's hosts. However, the reality is that things are never that straightforward for Les Parisiens or any other Ligue 1 sides when they travel to Brittany to face Les Guingampais.\n\nThe Spanish tactician knows this well. He watched his team lose 2-1 there last December and only a 5-0 thrashing of Lorient at Parc des Princes to end 2016 was enough to prevent the Basque from being sacked for the humiliation of going down to Guingamp.\n\nThat was not the first time that the Bretons had humiliated their illustrious capital city visitors either. Back in December of 2014, and with the mighty Zlatan Ibrahimovic in the starting XI, then-coach Jocelyn Gourvennec engineered another memorable result just days after PSG had been beaten 3-1 by Barcelona at Camp Nou in the UEFA Champions League group stages.\n\nGuingamp is a tough away day in Ligue 1, and although everybody enjoys the spectacle created by the passionate supporters at their intimate venue, nobody relishes playing in that sort of intimidating environment on a tight pitch that is often far from in pristine condition.\n\nOn top of all of this, the hosts have already sold enough tickets for the encounter to set a record attendance at the Roudourou.\n\nIt is as close to an English Premier League road match against the likes of Bournemouth, Burnley or Swansea as you will get in Le Championnat, and it is likely to show Neymar the sort of football and atmosphere that he will have rarely experienced in Spain and might have thought did not exist in France.\n\nAs Emery put it in his pre-match news conference at Camp des Loges on Friday, Guingamp will be \"up for it.\"\n\n\"We respect all of our opponents a lot,\" the 45-year-old told journalists. \"Guingamp enjoyed a great season last time campaign, they have won their first match this term and their stadium will be packed for our visit.\n\n\"All of our opponents are highly motivated each time they play us -- they want to push us around and cause an upset. We must prepare thoroughly for this match. We know that it will be difficult -- we lost there last season -- but we need to get a result, so we will go for the win.\n\n\"The players all know that it will be complicated and that there will be an intimidating atmosphere. Everyone has warned the new recruits that this sort of game will not be easy.\n\n\"I think that Guingamp absolutely want to see Neymar play. It would be great for everyone, notably their fans at the ground.\"\n\nIt promises to be quite the debut for Neymar. The Brazil international will get little time on the ball and will almost certainly be on the receiving end of some hefty challenges from some of the French top flight's most physical players.\n\nOn top of that, Kombouare -- a PSG legend and former coach -- has a good record against the club and will have his troops motivated to get in the visitors' faces.\n\nGuingamp's former PSG youth academy graduate Jordan Ikoko summed up the occasion of Neymar's debut quite well when speaking with L'Equipe earlier in the week.\n\n\"This is the first time in my career that I will come up against a genuinely world-class player,\" he said, despite having faced the likes of former teammates Edinson Cavani and Marco Verratti, as well as Angel Di Maria, before. \"Like everybody at Guingamp, I will be disappointed if he is not there.\n\n\"I will not concoct an anti-Neymar plan. It does not exist! The whole team must be at its best,\" Ikoko said. \"There is Neymar, but there are also 10 other players. I am a defender, I will not drop my head if he nutmegs me. It is Neymar, you have to expect that from him.\"\n\nGuingamp know to expect the unexpected from Neymar, but can the same be said of the 25-year-old towards his maiden Ligue 1 opponents?\n\nThe man from Mogi das Cruzes is about to get his first taste of the non-Champions League part of the challenge that he has taken on by moving to PSG from Barca, and it promises to be fascinating for all involved.\n\nJonathan Johnson covers PSG and the French national team for ESPN FC. Twitter: @Jon_LeGossip.", "time": "22:41:00"}

running - maintaining hope a deal will be struck.\n\nMonaco are adamant they will not accept less than their asking price - and are reluctant to sell to domestic rivals PSG.\n\nCity have long-believed He will be able to play on Sunday,\" said the LFP on Friday.\n\nNeymar is poised to make his much-anticipated debut for Paris Saint-Germain on Sunday when they travel to Guingamp in their second game of the Ligue 1 season.\n\nThe French Football Federation finally received the necessary documents to register the Brazilian on Friday after Barcelona confirmed the 222 million-euro ($261 million) cheque used to pay his buyout clause had cleared.\n\n\"Neymar's contract will be ratified during the afternoon. He will be able to play on Sunday,\" said the LFP on Friday.\n\nThe world's most expensive player should therefore run out into the mundane surroundings of the Stade du Roduourou -- capacity just over 15,000 -- in the tiny Brittany town of barely 7,000 people.\n\n\"Quite honestly it's better if he's there, much better,\" said Guingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, a former PSG player and Paris coach from 2009 to 2011.\n\n\"For us it is an extra source of motivation. We know that by beating PSG with Neymar it would be even more momentous.\n\n\"If Neymar is there it is all the better for the spectacle, for the supporters and for those who want to see him play, but we will be ready with or without him.\"\n\nNeymar was unveiled to the PSG fans at the Parc des Princes last weekend but was forced to watch from the stands as his new team-mates cruised to a low-key 2-0 win over newly-promoted Amiens in their Ligue 1 opener.\n\nThe 25-year-old Brazilian scored 105 goals in his four seasons at Barcelona, and his new team will be expecting him to score far more over the next few years.\n\nAlthough the main goal for the capital club is to finally challenge for the Champions League crown, their first task this term will be to retake the Ligue 1 title from Monaco.\n\nBETTER WITH NEYMAR\n\nCoach Unai Emery has no doubt that his new arrival will help the team achieve those lofty goals.\n\n\"He's a player who will help the club get to a higher level,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"Without Neymar PSG is a great club, but with Neymar it's a little better.\n\n\"The way we will adapt being close to a player like him... The other players here are also some great players, so together we can get better and grow.\"\n\nOnce again, PSG's main rivals for domestic honours appear to be Monaco, but they are in serious danger of losing rising star Kylian Mbappe to the capital outfit.\n\nThe 18-year-old, who is also wanted by Real Madrid, started in their opening 3-2 victory over Toulouse last weekend, as captain Radamel Falcao found the net.\n\nLeonardo Jardim's principality outfit will be expecting to make it two wins from two when they pay a visit to Dijon on Sunday.\n\nNice, who have the first leg of their Champions League play-off against Napoli on Wednesday, kick off the second weekend at home to promoted Troyes on Friday without their two star players, the injured Mario Balotelli and new signing Wesley Sneijder.\n\nLyon's youthful side started with a 4-0 thumping of Strasbourg last week and travel out to Brittany to take on Rennes on Friday.\n\nMarseille visit Claudio Ranieri's Nantes on Saturday looking to build on their 3-0 win over Dijon last time out but with captain Dimitri Payet missing due to injury.\n\nNantes v Marseille (6pm), Amiens v Angers (9pm), Bordeaux v Metz (9pm), Caen v Saint-Etienne (9pm), Toulouse v Montpellier (9pm)\n\nSunday\n\nStrasbourg v Lille (4pm), Dijon v Monaco (6pm), Guingamp v Paris Saint-Germain (10pm)", "time": "13:09:00"}

as soon as Monday\n\nPARIS SAINT-GERMAIN have followed up their world-record capture of Neymar by landing French sensation Kylian Mbappe for a staggering \u00a3160million.\n\nReal Madrid had been favourites to land the Monaco starlet after he burst on to the scene last season.\n\nBut it is the Qatari-backed French side who have won the race, with PSG's players told that the 18-year-old is set to be unveiled at the Parc des Princes as soon as Monday.\n\nNOT PICKED YOUR FANTASY FOOTBALL TEAM YET? WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?\n\nAnd the mega \u00a3360m double swoop is set to turn Ligue 1 into a one-team procession while PSG aim to slay the best in Europe.\n\nMonaco had been insistent they wanted to hold on to the teenager despite the interest from Real.\n\nBut Mbappe's father convinced Monaco to let the youngster leave this summer instead of hanging on for another 12 months.\n\nThat gave PSG the green light to begin negotiations over a mega-deal for the striker, with agreement reached swiftly once they were happy to match Madrid's offer.\n\nMbappe was convinced after a meeting with PSG boss Unai Emery that he would play a huge role in the starting side this season -- despite the \u00a3198m spent to lure Neymar from the Nou Camp.\n\nThe signing is another huge statement of intent by PSG after they landed Neymar from Barcelona in a deal that saw questions asked over Uefa's Financial Fair Play regime.\n\nIn total, PSG have spent a eye-watering \u00a3372.5m this summer, with Spanish left-back Yuri Berchiche (\u00a314.5m) and Brazilian right-back Dani Alves (free) also arriving in the French capital.\n\nUefa introduced break-even FFP rules in 2013 to stop clubs accumulating too much debt and to prevent wealthy owners from injecting too much cash into their clubs.\n\nThe rules state that over a three-year period a club like PSG, owned by the Gulf state of Qatar, can spend 30m euros more than it earns.\n\nPSG could also offload players to balance the books.\n\nFor Real, losing out on \u00a3200,000-a-week Mbappe is a hammer blow and could see them crank up their interest in Chelsea's Eden Hazard.\n\nMeanwhile, Real's rivals Barcelona also suffered a setback in the market after Borussia Dortmund rejected a bid, understood to be worth \u00a390m, for Ousmane Dembele.\n\nBut the wantaway France striker, 20, has been suspended by the German giants until next week after missing training.\n\nDortmund coach Peter Bosz said: \"We don't know why. We tried to reach him but we were unable to.\"\n\nThe Bundesliga outfit claim a possible Nou Camp move for Dembele, lined up as a replacement for Neymar, is unlikely because the offer did not reflect his \"extraordinary\" value in the current state of the transfer market.\n\nA club statement read: \"As there is no other offer on the table, a transfer by the player to FC Barcelona is not at this time expected, nor currently very likely.\"\n\nIt is thought Dortmund are holding out for \u00a3140m for their rising star but Barca are not willing to match that fee.\n\nIf the answer is no you need to take a long, hard look at yourself.\n\nBecause the Dream Team game - the UK's biggest fantasy football game - is back and better than ever this season.\n\nYou've got a \u00a350m budget to pick 11 players, with all the biggest new signings ready and raring to go ahead of a mouthwatering new Premier League campaign.", "time": "21:36:00"}

Paris Saint-Germain debut on Sunday focus switched from his record transfer fee to the question of which star would make way for the Brazilian.\n\nLe Parisien daily newspaper suggested it would be Javier Pastore, the silky but fragile Argentine who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners, who splashed out a world record 222 million-euro ($261 million) for Neymar.\n\nNew Paris Saint-Germain signing Neymar Jr poses with the club shirt. Reuters\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" one Le Parisien headline asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left last season, only to hand it to the Brazilian this season.\n\n\"Neymar will start on the left at the cost of Pastore,\" the article claimed.\n\n\"So it'll be Neymar, (Edinson) Cavani and without doubt (Angel) di Maria in a three pronged attack,\" said Le Parisien, which then gave a long list of top signings who will be warming the PSG bench.\n\nAlongside Pastore will be the Brazilian Lucas Moura, who is rumoured to be staying as he has been friends with Neymar since the age of nine, and Germany captain at the Confederations Cup Julian Draxler, who arrived just last year in a big money transfer of his own.\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar - the football version,\" ran their headline in a joke about how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news without the 25-year-old forward even kicking a ball yet.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and di Maria will support Cavani,\" they predicted, but were unsure where the extra man would be cut.\n\nThe only sure thing is that Neymar will start.\n\n\"He's physically ready to play the whole ninety minutes,\" PSG coach Unai Emery told AFP.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nGuingamp coach Antoine Kombouare, himself a former PSG manager, also wants Neymar to play.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win, preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar,\" he claimed. \"The people here support their team.\"\n\nIn the tiny Brittany town of Guingamp, with a population of around 7,000, tickets for the match have been changing hands for a king's ransom as the Stade du Rouduorou has a capacity of just over 17,000.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat told local newspaper Le Telegramme.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible,\" he said.\n\nJournalists however may find themselves a bit squeezed for space as the rustic press tribune allowing for 80 press seats has been extended to a blockbuster 350.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 12, 2017 09:13 pm | Updated Date: Aug 12, 2017 09:13 pm\n\nTags :#Angel di maria#Cavani#Guingamp#Kickingaround#Lucas moura#Neymar#Paris#Paris-saint germain#Psg#Unai emery#Zlatan ibrahimovic", "time": "15:57:00"}

focus switched from his record transfer fee to the question of which star would make way for the Brazilian.\n\nLe Parisien daily newspaper suggested it would be Javier Pastore, the silky but fragile up his No.10 shirt, will he (Pastore) now give him (Neymar) his place in the team?\" one Le Parisien headline asked of the player who took up the No.10 shirt after Zlatan Ibrahimovic left last season, Maria in a three pronged attack,\" said Le Parisien, which then gave a long list of top signings who will be warming the PSG bench.\n\nAlongside Pastore will be the Brazilian Lucas Moura, who is rumoured to be staying as he has been friends with Neymar since the age of nine, and Germany captain at the Confederations Cup Julian Draxler, who arrived just last year in a big money transfer of his own.\n\nSports daily L'Equipe saw things differently, though.\n\n\"Neymar -- the football version,\" ran their headline in a joke about how the most expensive transfer in football history has dominated news without the 25-year-old forward even kicking a ball yet.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and di Maria will support Cavani,\" they predicted, but were unsure where the extra man would be cut.\n\nThe only sure thing is that Neymar will start.\n\n\"He's been working well and we looked hard at tactics and free-kicks,\" said the Spaniard.\n\n\"We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nGuingamp coach Antoine Kombouarhimself a former PSG manager, also wants Neymar to play.\n\n\"I want the fans to come Sunday to see Guingamp win... preferably against a side with Neymar in it.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar,\" he claimed. \"The people here support their team.\"\n\nIn the tiny Brittany town of Guingamp, with a population of around 7,000, tickets for the match have been changing hands for a king's ransom as the Stade du Rouduorou has a capacity of just over 17,000.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat told local newspaper Le Telegramme.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible,\" he said.\n\nJournalists however may find themselves a bit squeezed for space as the rustic press tribune allowing for 80 press seats has been extended to a blockbuster 350.", "time": "17:29:00"}

Photo: Kamil Zihnioglu, AP\n\nPARIS - Neymar will watch from the stands as Paris Saint-Germain open their season Saturday, but the French club have already clawed back around a million euros on their world record investment thanks to selling a staggering 10 000 shirts bearing the Brazilian's name in just one day.\n\nThe 25-year-old superstar, signed from Barcelona for a mind-boggling \u20ac222 million (about R3.53 billion), will be presented to the PSG support prior to his new team's first game of the Ligue 1 campaign against promoted Amiens.\n\nA ceremony will begin at 3.45pm French time, with the kickoff put back quarter of an hour to 5.15pm to allow extra time for the player's unveiling before an expected sell-out crowd of more than 45 000 at the Parc des Princes.\n\nHowever, Neymar's hopes of playing in the match were dashed when his international transfer certificate failed to be lodged with the French league by the midnight deadline on Friday.\n\n\"I am ready to start on Saturday if I can,\" he said before falling victim to the constraints of paperwork.\n\nThe @neymarjr era at PSG has begun!! \u1f534\u1f535#BemvindoNeymarJr \u1f1e7\u1f1f7 pic.twitter.com/nMpKWKckHc\n\n-- PSG English (@PSG_English) August 4, 2017\n\nDespite the minor setback, Neymar has already started repaying his mammoth transfer fee.\n\nPSG said that more than 10 000 shirts bearing his name and his new number No 10 were sold on Friday.\n\nAt an average of \u20ac100 each, PSG generated \u20ac1 million even before he had kicked a ball.\n\nMoney was the subject of most of the questions fired at the Brazilian when he was unveiled to the media on Friday after arriving in the French capital on a private jet.\n\nHowever, Neymar, who is poised to earn around \u20ac30m a year, insisted financial gain was not a factor.\n\n\"I want something bigger, a greater challenge. I am here to give my best and help the club win titles,\" said Neymar, who signed a five-year contract with the Qatar-owned club.\n\n\u1f4fd @NeymarJR's first interview in Paris \u1f534\u1f535\n\n\u1f1e7\u1f1f7 #BemvindoNeymarJR pic.twitter.com/ZqBDx8kVeb\n\n-- PSG English (@PSG_English) August 4, 2017\n\nHe insisted he had come to France \"for the ambition of the club, which is very similar to mine.\"\n\nNeymar admitted that leaving Barcelona, where he formed part of a lethal attacking trio with Lionel Messi and Luis Suarez, was not a decision he took lightly.\n\n\"It was one of my most difficult decisions. In Barcelona, I had adapted well to the city and the team. I had friends there and it has not been easy,\" he said.\n\n\"It was a tense time, thinking about what I should do in my life. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_Financial_Fair_Play_Regulations", "label": {"eng": "UEFA Financial Fair Play Regulations"}, "score": 4, "type": "wiki", "id": "455235"}], "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/football/1406233/psg-are-now-the-biggest-club-in-world-football-as-les-galacticos-blow-financial-fair-play-out-of-the-water/", "body": "Kylian Mbappe signing a week after Neymar deals leaves Uefa rules dead and buried as French club create a new world order with worrying ramifications for the rest of football\n\nPARIS SAINT-GERMAIN'S signing of Kylian Mbappe has confirmed their status as Les Galacticos - and ensured Financial Fair Play is dead in the water.\n\nTeenager Mbappe is set to complete a \u00a3160million move from Monaco after PSG won the race to land one of the most exciting prospects in world football.\n\nJust a week after the Qatari-backed club landed Neymar in a world-record \u00a3198m move from Barcelona, it has confirmed the Paris club are have now moved to the top of the tree.\n\nNOT PICKED YOUR FANTASY FOOTBALL TEAM YET? WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?\n\nAnd it has also ended once and for all the charade of Uefa's FFP regulations.\n\nPSG have muscled their way into becoming the biggest clubs on the planet in the space of a fortnight.\n\nWhile the likes of Real Madrid, Barcelona and Manchester United have built their status on the back of years of success on the field, PSG have reached that level with two bank transfer payments.\n\nAny club who can sign one of the biggest superstars in world football, and follow it up with the capture of the best young talent in the game, are punching at a seriously high level.\n\nTraditionalists may not be happy, and nor will some of the other big clubs in Europe who are desperate to protect their own status, but a team who has never won the European Cup is now dictating the future of football.\n\nWhen Uefa introduced their FFP rules there was always a scepticism over their motives - and whether they could ever really enforce them.\n\nThe traditional big clubs around Europe were happy because on paper FFP helped protect them and prevent upstarts from gatecrashing the party.\n\nOthers thought they didn't do enough to provide the framework to stop clubs operating beyond their means.\n\nThere have been suspicions in the past some clubs have bent the rules in order to sign a player or two - but PSG have essentially blown the whole system out of the water.\n\nThe \u00a3198m Neymar release clause is not going through their books, instead it has been met by the Qatari investment fund who own the club as a private commercial sponsorship deal.\n\nQuite where the \u00a3160m to sign Mbappe is coming from is anyone's guess - but the reality is PSG are benefiting from the arrival of two players worth \u00a3358m when they simply do not have the revenue streams to comply with FFP.\n\nGiven these deals won't have to be presented until the 2018/19 accounts, they have the freedom conjure up ways to present their books to Uefa in a way that meets the regulations.\n\nAnd if they do fall foul of them, what is the punishment? A hefty fine which will mean absolutely nothing.\n\nA transfer embargo would also do little damage, because by that point PSG would have amassed a squad so strong they wouldn't have to worry.\n\nBut those potential sanctions are all in the future in any case. In the meantime, PSG can go on their merry way doing whatever they want and to hell with the consequences.\n\nFFP is dead in the water.\n\nBut what else does this mad summer mean for the future of football?\n\nBy virtue of winning the European Cup for the past two seasons, Real Madrid have to be considered favourites to make it a hat-trick this season.\n\nBut PSG have now assembled a side that has to be feared across the continent and are serious contenders to win the competition for the first time\n\nNeymar and Mbappe make up a fearsome attacking unit when you combine them with Edinson Cavani.\n\nBut it is not just that trio of top class talents in their squad - Julian Draxler, Lucas Moura, Marco Verratti, Javier Pastore, Thiago Motta and Thiaga Silva. The list just goes on and on.\n\nIt is a squad of astonishing depth and quality and puts them right up there as one of the two sides to beat in the Champions League this season.\n\nMore worrying perhaps is that the business the club have done could ultimately threaten the financial viability of other clubs across Europe.\n\nPSG haven't just assembled a squad the envy of world football, they have changed the face of the game forever.\n\nIt is all well and good being bankrolled by an oil-rich country, but there are few clubs who can dip into that kind of resource and survive.\n\nThe problem is, the Neymar and Mbappe deals set a new benchmark in transfers - both in terms of the size of fee and the market rate for salaries.\n\nThe effect will be an inflation in player and agent demands that will see clubs across Europe having to stretch beyond their means to make a signing in order to keep up with the rest.\n\nNot just at the highest level with the elite clubs, but the drip down will filter through to the domestic leagues and below as the going rate and demands get ever bigger.\n\nClubs are going to be saddled with crippling debts and wage bills over the coming few years at levels few can imagine.\n\nThere are some who say football is already morally bankrupt. Financially, it could well be in the next five years.\n\nHaving not even won the French League last season, it may seem a ridiculous notion but PSG risk killing the long-term future of their domestic competition.\n\nMonaco were brilliant as they won the title last season, but the harsh realities of the modern game mean that squad has been torn apart as Europe's elite picked off their best talent.\n\nSo the Monaco side that has started the defence of their crown is not anything like the team of champions that went before.\n\nPSG, on the other hand, have riches in talent beyond the wildest dreams of their rivals in Ligue 1 and as they continue to strengthen, so their dominance over their home rivals is in danger of growing.\n\nIt is in danger of becoming a one-club league, with others so far behind and lacking the financial muscle to do anything about it.\n\nLack of competition means lack of interest, from supporters going through the turnstiles to corporate sponsors and television companies making lucrative deals.\n\nThe struggles of the Scottish game is an example the French League will be desperate to avoid - but they might not be able to do anything to prevent it.\n\nKeep up to date with ALL the latest transfer news and speculation with our live transfer feed\n\nIf the answer is no you need to take a long, hard look at yourself.\n\nBecause the Dream Team game - the UK's biggest fantasy football game - is back and better than ever this season.\n\nYou've got a \u00a350m budget to pick 11 players, with all the biggest new signings ready and raring to go ahead of a mouthwatering new Premier League campaign.", "time": "10:04:00"}

his record transfer fee to the question of which star would make way for the Brazilian.\n\nLe Parisien daily newspaper suggested it would be Javier Pastore, the silky but fragile Argentine who was the first major signing after PSG were bought by their ambitious Qatari owners, who splashed out a world record 222 million-euro (USD 261 million) for Neymar.\n\n\"After first giving up his No.10 shirt, pronged attack,\" said Le Parisien, which then gave a long list of top signings who will be warming the PSG bench.\n\nAlongside Pastore will be the Brazilian Lucas Moura, who is rumoured to be staying as he has been friends with Neymar since the age of nine, and Germany captain at the Confederations Cup Julian Draxler, who arrived just last year in a big money transfer of his own.\n\nSports daily 25-year-old forward even kicking a ball yet.\n\n\"A trio of Neymar, Pastore and di Maria will support Cavani,\" they predicted, but were unsure where the extra man would be cut.\n\nThe only sure thing said the Spaniard.\n\n\"We all want him in the starting eleven, he's a player we need in the group.\"\n\nGuingamp coach Antoine Kombouar , himself a former PSG manager, also wants Neymar to play.\n\n\"But the people here are not talking about Neymar,\" he claimed. \"The people here support their team.\" In the tiny Brittany town of Guingamp, with a population of around 7,000, tickets for the match have been changing hands for a king's ransom as the Stade du Rouduorou has a capacity of just over 17,000.\n\n\"We could have filled a stadium of 40,000 seats with no problem at all,\" Guingamp president Bertrand Desplat told local newspaper Le Telegramme.\n\n\"Remember the star of the show is going to be Neymar and for us we want to welcome this very special player and his team in the best conditions possible,\" he said.\n\nJournalists however may find themselves a bit squeezed for space as the rustic press tribune allowing for 80 press seats has been extended to a blockbuster Photo: EPA\n\nNeymar says he is \"extremely happy\" to join Paris Saint-Germain after signing a five-year contract with the French giants.\n\nPSG announced on their website late on Thursday night that they have formally acquired the Brazilian's services until June 30, 2022 after his buyout clause of a world-record \u20ac222 million (about R3.53 billion) was paid to Barcelona earlier in the day.\n\nIt is more than double the amount Manchester United paid Juventus to sign Paul Pogba last year for \u20ac105 million.\n\n\"I am extremely happy to join Paris Saint-Germain. He's left behind one of the most famous sporting institutions in the world for a club that is younger than Jennifer Aniston, and is expected to pocket in excess of \u00a3500,000, after tax, each and every week in France.\n\nBut to accuse the Brazilian superstar of simply quitting Camp Nou for a huge pay day is the lazy criticism, and more than a little unfair.\n\nNeymar answered those critics in his own words on Friday: \"What I say to these people is they don't know anything about my personal life, I was never motivated by money.\n\n\"If I was following the money, I would be somewhere else, with other clubs in other countries. I'm really sad that people still think that way and I'm glad that PSG believe in me.\"\n\nA major theme of the 2013 autobiography Neymar co-wrote with his father centred on money not being a driving factor in his career. Together, they both explained how football was always the most important thing and that had money been a motivating factor the emerging player could have left Santos on several occasions in a lucrative deal before he eventually joined Bar\u00e7a at the age of 21.\n\nAs difficult as it is to push the money angle to one side, fans and critics must do so because Neymar was absolutely right to leave Barcelona for PSG for footballing reasons.\n\nThe message that Lionel Messi's recently signed new long-term contract effectively gave to Neymar was, 'This is still out guy for the next four year, not you'.\n\nMessi was apparently given terms that Neymar was told a year previously were impossible. That doesn't mean it's about the money itself, but rather parity and validation. How is Neymar supposed to feel when he is constantly told he'll soon be the best player in the world, but his club won't treat him as an equal to the star they expect him to match?\n\nIt has nothing to do with the personal relationship between the pair either. But Neymar, with ambition to be the greatest footballer on the planet, would have looked at the situation and seen Messi backed to remain number one at Camp Nou until 2021, by which time the Brazilian would be 29 and have potentially missed his best years still stuck in the shadows of a club hero.\n\nLeaving is not the easy option, staying and continuing to stay in those shadows would have been the far safer choice. He had a very good contract anyway, was still very highly thought of regardless of Messi being in front, and could easily have collected many more trophies.\n\nBut what Neymar has done by accepting the call from PSG is risk everything. He has backed himself and staked his whole reputation on proving that he can actually be the main man at the highest level, the world-leading superstar that his potential always suggested he would be.\n\nHe won't get plaudits for helping PSG to French titles or domestic cups, those were the minimum requirement at Parc des Princes for six years before Neymar arrived. Instead, the dream is the Champions League, to become only the second French club to be crowned European champions.\n\nPSG's only appearance in the old European Cup ended in a first round exit in 1986, while they have never been beyond the semi-finals in the Champions League. In fact, their only appearance in the last four actually came as far back as 1995, long before the current regime of Qatar-backed wealth.\n\nNeymar is presented with the challenge of creating history where there isn't much. At Bar\u00e7a, he would have remained just another face in the crowd, the latest on a long list of legends. No, PSG is the real challenge. PSG will give him the platform he needs, and the money is almost irrelevant.", "time": "07:15:00"}

eligible to make his PSG and Ligue 1 debut at Stade du Roudourou this weekend, with the French Football Federation confirming receipt of the certificate from its Spanish counterpart on Friday.\n\nAnd Emery revealed that Neymar is already in contention for a starting role against Antoine Kombouare's men.\n\n\"Guingamp is a very good away day,\" Neymar said. \"They are a team that will be well prepared after they beat Troyes. It will be a physical encounter but their team also possesses some quality. It will be a good test for us and for Neymar -- if he plays. It is difficult to win away from home in Spain, just like it is here.\"\n\nEmery has been getting to know Neymar over the course of the week and is convinced PSG's new No. 10 is ready for his maiden appearance.\n\n\"He has done well in training, where we have worked tactically and technically,\" he said. \"He is ready. He can be a part of the squad and he can play.\n\n\"We want him on the pitch because he is somebody we need. We are going to train on Saturday and then the staff will discuss the possibility [of him starting in Guingamp]. He is ready to start and in good physical condition to complete a full 90 minutes.\"\n\nEmery has already told Neymar what is expected of him and the PSG boss feels his new forward has already adapted well.\n\n\"He works hard and, like the others, he has his own habits while training and during lunch,\" Emery said. \"I have spoken with him in the same way that I have with the other players, about how we are going to play and how we work.\"\n\nSpeaking with PSG's official website, midfielder Adrien Rabiot said that Neymar signing for the club is a big deal but that he and his teammates have remained focused throughout the furore that surrounded the most expensive transfer ever.\n\n\"It is true that Neymar's arrival has caused quite a fuss,\" Rabiot said. \"People are happy and it has brought quite a lot of them together. All the fans rushed out to buy his shirt.\n\n\"It was a really big deal for the media but among us players, we were focused on the opening match against Amiens. We wanted to start with a good result at home.\n\n\"We are happy to have him, though, because he is a great player. He is going to be a plus for the team and will help us in our goals -- he will settle in easily thanks to the other Brazilian players and he is young, so we are interested in the same things, I have no doubt.\"\n\nA source has told ESPN FC that Monaco forward Kylian Mbappe is keen on a move to Parc des Princes to link up with Neymar but that no agreement has been reached yet.\n\nQuestioned on PSG's interest in the 18-year-old, Emery was evasive and more reserved on the topic than he was earlier this summer when he admitted his interest in him.\n\n\"I am only talking about players who are here,\" Emery said. \"I do not know what is going to happen over the next few days but he is a Monaco player right now.\"\n\nEmery also fielded a question on midfielder Marco Verratti and how he has digested Barcelona's failed move for his services this summer.\n\n\"I feel like he is fine,\" Emery said. \"He was injured in Miami. He played in the Trophee des Champions against Monaco but was not 100 percent physically. There was no plan, but when he suggested I join PSG, it was supposedly because he was going to come too.\"\n\nAFP", "time": "11:10:00"}
